title.children: US debt ceiling bill heads to a vote as risk of default looms, ASX to slip over rate hike concerns

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mining giant BHP says it's identified issues with certain allowances and entitlement that affect nearly 30,000 current and former employees that's estimated to cost the company more than $400 million to correct. In a statement to the ASX, BHP says a review suggests rostered employees in Australia had their leave incorrectly deducted on public holidays since 2010. "There are approximately 28,500 affected current and former employees with an average of six leave days in total that have been incorrectly deducted from affected employees," they told the ASX. BHP also said it's found around 400 current and former employees in Port Hedland are entitled to additional allowances "due to an error with the employment entity in their contract". BHP estimates the cost of fixing the issue will be around $US280 million pre-tax — which works out to be roughly $430 million. Geraldine Slattery, BHP's Australian President has apologised to the employees affected by the errors. "This is not good enough and falls short of the standards we expect at BHP," she said. "We are working to rectify and remediate these issues, with interest, as quickly as possible." BHP says it has self-reported to the Fair Work Ombudsman, and will contact current and former employees who have been affected.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BHP investigating potential underpayment of nearly 30,000 workers over 13 years

children.content: Mining giant BHP says it's identified issues with certain allowances and entitlement that affect nearly 30,000 current and former employees that's estimated to cost the company more than $400 million to correct.
In a statement to the ASX, BHP says a review suggests rostered employees in Australia had their leave incorrectly deducted on public holidays since 2010.
"There are approximately 28,500 affected current and former employees with an average of six leave days in total that have been incorrectly deducted from affected employees," they told the ASX.
BHP also said it's found around 400 current and former employees in Port Hedland are entitled to additional allowances "due to an error with the employment entity in their contract".
BHP estimates the cost of fixing the issue will be around $US280 million pre-tax — which works out to be roughly $430 million.
Geraldine Slattery, BHP's Australian President has apologised to the employees affected by the errors.
"This is not good enough and falls short of the standards we expect at BHP," she said.
"We are working to rectify and remediate these issues, with interest, as quickly as possible."
BHP says it has self-reported to the Fair Work Ombudsman, and will contact current and former employees who have been affected.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Online retail giant Amazon has been ordered to pay more than $US25 million ($38 million) to settle allegations it violated children's privacy rights with its Alexa voice assistant. The company has agreed to pay the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) after it was accused of failing to delete Alexa recordings at the request of parents. It was found to have kept hold of sensitive data for years. Amazon's doorbell camera unit Ring will also pay almost $9 million to authorities, after giving employees unrestricted access to customers' data. "As a result of this dangerously overbroad access and lax attitude toward privacy and security, employees and third-party contractors were able to view, download, and transfer customers' sensitive video data," the FTC said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Amazon to pay more than $38m over privacy violations with Alexa and Ring products

Amazon
has been ordered to pay more than $US25 million ($38 million) to settle allegations it
violated children's privacy rights with its Alexa voice assistant
The company has agreed to pay the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) after it was accused of failing to delete Alexa recordings at the request of parents.
It was found to have kept hold of sensitive data for years.
Amazon's doorbell camera unit
Ring
will also pay almost $9 million to authorities, after giving employees
unrestricted access to customers' data

"As a result of this dangerously overbroad access and lax attitude toward privacy and security, employees and third-party contractors were able to view, download, and transfer customers' sensitive video data," the FTC said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're still paying off your HECS-HELP debt, I have some bad news for you — your debt is going up today. That's because the loans are being indexed today at a rate of 7.1%. This happens every year to bring debts in line with inflation, but it's a sharp increase compared to years gone by. Last year, it was 3.9%, and the year before it was a 0.6% increase. Overall the change will affect more than 3 million debts. If you're wanting to know how much more you'll be paying on your HECS-HELP debt, you can find out with the calculator below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Happening today: HECS-HELP debts are going up

featuredLink.title: HECS-HELP loans are indexed today. Check how much your loan will increase with our calculator

children.content: If you're still paying off your HECS-HELP debt, I have some bad news for you — your debt is going up today.
That's because the loans are being indexed today at a rate of 7.1%.
This happens every year to bring debts in line with inflation, but it's a sharp increase compared to years gone by.
Last year, it was 3.9%, and the year before it was a 0.6% increase.
Overall the change will affect
more than 3 million debts
